statement: F. Choose a Squaretime limit per test6 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputPetya recently found a game "Choose a Square". In this game, there are $$$n$$$ points numbered from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ on an infinite field. The $$$i$$$-th point has coordinates $$$(x_i, y_i)$$$ and cost $$$c_i$$$.You have to choose a square such that its sides are parallel to coordinate axes, the lower left and upper right corners belong to the line $$$y = x$$$, and all corners have integer coordinates.The score you get is the sum of costs of the points covered by the selected square minus the length of the side of the square. Note that the length of the side can be zero.Petya asks you to calculate the maximum possible score in the game that can be achieved by placing exactly one square.InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 5 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the number of points on the field.Each of the following $$$n$$$ lines contains three integers $$$x_i, y_i, c_i$$$ ($$$0 \\le x_i, y_i \\le 10^9, -10^6 \\le c_i \\le 10^6$$$) — coordinates of the $$$i$$$-th point and its cost, respectively.OutputIn the first line print the maximum score Petya can achieve.In the second line print four integers $$$x_1, y_1, x_2, y_2$$$ ($$$0 \\le x_1, y_1, x_2, y_2 \\le 2 \\cdot 10^9, x_1 = y_1, x_2 = y_2, x_1 \\le x_2$$$) separated by spaces — the coordinates of the lower left and upper right corners of the square which Petya has to select in order to achieve the maximum score.ExamplesInput6 0 0 2 1 0 -5 1 1 3 2 3 4 1 4 -4 3 1 -1Output4 1 1 3 3Input5 3 3 0 3 3 -3 0 2 -1 3 1 3 0 0 -2Output0 1 1 1 1NoteThe field corresponding to the first example:

You are given $n$ points on a plane, each with coordinates $(x_i, y_i)$ and a cost $c_i$.  You need to choose a square whose sides are parallel to the coordinate axes, with its bottom-left and top-right corners lying on the line $y=x$.  The score you get is the sum of the costs of the points inside the square, minus the length of a side of the square.  Find the maximum possible score and the coordinates of the square that achieves it. 

The input consists of:

* A line with an integer $n$ (the number of points).
* $n$ lines, each with three integers $x_i$, $y_i$, and $c_i$ (the coordinates and cost of each point).

The output consists of:

* A line with the maximum score.
* A line with four integers $x_1$, $y_1$, $x_2$, $y_2$ (the coordinates of the bottom-left and top-right corners of the square).

You are given a set of points on a grid, each with a value. You need to find the largest square you can draw on the grid, where the square's corners must lie on the line y=x, and the square's sides are parallel to the grid lines. The score is the sum of the values of the points inside the square minus the length of a side of the square. What is the maximum score you can achieve?  Also, report the coordinates of the square's corners.
